results.headline: Looking at Sex and Laughing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sleeping Dogs Lie

results.summary_short: The uncomfortable message sent by Bobcat Goldthwait's lean, subversive comedy is how easy it is to gross out people who think they're so swinging and cool.

results.headline: Mom’s Wacky, Dad’s Distracted, Son Survives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Running with Scissors

results.summary_short: From Augusten Burroughs’s best-selling memoir,  a showcase of high-quality acting (especially from Annette Bening) without much in the way of dramatic coherence or emotional power.

results.headline: A Mind in Torment Faces a Terrible Decline

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Requiem

results.summary_short: Hans-Christian Schmid's thoughtful drama is loosely based on the real-life story of a West German woman who died in 1976 after a series of failed exorcisms.

results.headline: Courageous Teenagers on a Sacred Quest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Masai: the Rain Warriors

results.summary_short: Set in the highlands of Kenya,  “Masai: The Rain Warriors” is the debut fictional film of Pascal Plisson, a devoted nature documentarian.

results.headline: Whoa, Girl: Taming a Wild Child

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flicka

results.summary_short: Girl meets horse yet again in this entertainingly ridiculous update of Mary O’Hara’s 1941 children’s novel, “My Friend Flicka.”

results.headline: Opposites Attract at the 2004 Republican Convention

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Conventioneers

results.summary_short: Scripted drama interfaces with real world events in this smart, resourceful indie staged during the 2004 Republican Convention in New York City.

results.headline: A Foreign Bride in a Strange Land

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sweet Land

results.summary_short: Ali Selim’s “Sweet Land” is an unabashedly sentimental tale of a mail-order bride and the community that eventually comes to accept her.

results.headline: Where the Mascot Is More of a Stud than the Quarterback

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hair High

results.summary_short: In the gleefully outrageous animated feature “Hair High,” director Bill Plympton walks the border between ridiculously gross and outright offensive.

results.headline: Scenes From a Marriage, Revealed by a Son

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 51 Birch Street

results.summary_short: In “51 Birch Street,” a moving and fascinating documentary, Doug Block investigates the lingering, buried frustration in his parents’ otherwise ordinary lives.

results.headline: A Walk Through the Bowels of Brazilian Justice

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Justice

results.summary_short: Justice often moves painfully slowly, and so does “Justice” (“Justiça”), a documentary by Maria Ramos about low-level criminal courts in Brazil.

results.headline: A Soldier Amid Crooks, Alligators and Fireballs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Marine

results.summary_short: The professional wrestler and hip-hop artist John Cena makes his big-screen debut with a role that demands extensive knowledge of bodybuilding and melees but little else.

results.headline: The Usual Cast of Victims, in Order of Stupidity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grudge 2

results.summary_short: Puberty causes an exponential increase in evil — and in incoherence — in the second installment in Takashi Shimizu’s saga about a Japanese wraith with a fondness for neck-snapping and Goth makeup.

results.headline: A Lonely Petit Four of a Queen

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marie Antoinette

results.summary_short: Highly theatrical and yet also intimate and informal, Sofia Coppola’s “Marie Antoinette” lets its story slink almost casually through its lovingly composed and rendered images.

results.headline: Truman Capote’s Journey on 'In Cold Blood,' Again

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Infamous

results.summary_short: There is no reason to choose between Bennett Miller’s "Capote" and Douglas McGrath’s "Infamous." Both stand out above the biopic pack.

results.headline: The Lives of Priest and Victims in the Silence After the Anguish

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deliver Us From Evil

results.summary_short: Neither sensationalistic nor sentimental, Amy Berg’s documentary about the sexual abuse scandals in the Roman Catholic Church is clear-sighted, tough-minded and devastating.

results.headline: A Rare Condition Leads to a New Definition of Gender Bending

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zerophilia

results.summary_short: Androgyny rules in Martin Curland’s audacious feature about a fictional chromosomal abnormality that plays hell with one’s genitals.

results.headline: A Girl Endures a No-Man’s Land by Dwelling in the Make-Believe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tideland

results.summary_short: Terry Gilliam aims for the borderline between fantasy and reality, but instead stumbles into a no-man’s land between the merely bad and the completely indefensible.

results.headline: The Adventures of a Junior James Bond

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alex Rider: Operation Stormbreaker

results.summary_short: Based on the first in a series of best-selling children's novels, the movie debut of Alex Rider is a James Bond flick for kids who never heard of James Bond.

results.headline: Remembering a Small but Important Contribution to the Greatest Generation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ritchie Boys

results.summary_short: Christian Bauer's documentary tells of a group of Jewish immigrants who fled Germany for the United States in the years of the Nazi buildup.

results.headline: Joke the Vote: A Comedian for President

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Man of the Year

results.summary_short: In a pre-election season full of drama, contention and surprise, “Man of the Year” arrives on the scene with the blistering impact of a spoonful of cold mashed potatoes.
